original_title: Sri Lanka’s shares edge down on selling pressure
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s shares edged down in mid-day trade on Tuesday, as selling pressures take on the market evidently seen on the construction index as import bans are to come off, an analyst said.
The main All Share Price Index was down 0.28 percent or 23.73 points to 8,587.65, while the most liquid index S&P SL20 was down 0.03 percent or 0.84 points to 2,433.47.
The market generated a turnover of 410 million rupees during 1200 hours.
“There is selling pressures on the construction index as bans are to come off, expecting lower turnover on revenue, ” an analyst said.
Sri Lanka has expressed its intention to present a plan by June to lift import restrictions, while the government has promised the European Union (EU) that it will gradually relax the restrictions.
In March, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) too revealed that Sri Lanka was expected to phase out the import and exchange restrictions currently in place.

IMF Mission Chief Masahiro Nozaki said Sri Lankan authorities will develop a plan for the phased removal of import restrictions and exchange restrictions related to the balance of payments (BOP), which is due by June 2023.
Top losers were Vallibel One, Hatton National Bank and Teejay Lanka. (Colombo/May23/2023)
